posts.name: chrisrin
posts.cooked:
I searched for a discussion like this & did not find one. If there is one, I would be glad to read it.

I appreciate 3847 Spectrum’s inclusion of failures & fixes in their competition debriefs that are part of their excellent built blog . It inspired me to start this discussion to crowdsource a list of the really common avoidable failures and how to avoid them.

We had a great season this year, improving in many ways over last, and we’re proud of our efforts and results. That said, we have a lot to learn. In particular, there are common failures we encountered that were avoidable… I’ll share a couple of them:

1. Failure: Our robot became disabled because its network switch’s barrel power connector came unplugged. How to Avoid: Hot glue the barrel power connector so it cannot come unplugged. (Thanks to our alliance partner for this advice… 4469 R.A.I.D. I believe)

2. Failure: We observed many robots driving around at times with mechanisms outside their bumpers (our team included), and in one case an opposing alliance robot became disabled & a red card elims loss resulted. How to Avoid: It seems like design & programming foresight + drive team training to deliberately avoid this are the ways to address this one. Our team did talk about this, but we still were not always as careful as we should have been.

What would you put on the list of avoidable common failures? I hate seeing robots disabled; let’s help each other avoid some of these!

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
Bad Ethernet cables: buy the ultra-flexible ones from Monoprice Networking issues: set static IPs in the correct range for your network devices. Also, make sure your radio power is good. Jostle it around. Wires getting unplugged: back up any wire connectors like Power poles or CAN connectors with zipties.

Hot glue everything in the critical power path. That includes radio power, network switch power, RoboRIO power, RPM power, and power inputs to the PDH. Make sure you don’t totally coat stuff so you can swap them out later.

posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked:
Loose main power wires?

Replace the main breaker nuts with nylon locking nuts.

Use nordlocks too.

Here’s a common one that plagued my team as a student: forgetting to strap down battery/other robot tasks you do before every match

Solution: Checklists. And then making sure everyone checks the checklist.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FiM Alum, Just here for Goat news

posts.custom_user_title: FiM Alum, Just here for Goat news

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
Intake bearings: you should have your intake bearing flanges facing to the outside. Additionally you should retain them via screws or a bearing hat to ensure that the bearings don’t pop out of the plates.

Intake pnuematic placement: many teams design pnuematic intake linkages so the cylinder is extended when the intake is extended. While this works, this does mean that the cylinder is in its most vulnerable configuration when the intake is most likely to get hit. If you can, design it so your cylinder is retracted when the intake is extended.

Use inserts to reinforce printed hex bores: if you 3D print things like gears or pulleys or other things that transmit torque via a printed hex bore, consider using a 3D print insert to reinforce the hex bore to prevent it from rounding over. WCP and TTB sell these now, and some teams even buy 3/4" hex spacer from McMaster.

Have a long Ethernet cable (preferably spooled): when practicing at home you’ll likely be running your robot wirelessly however at competitions you’ll want a long Ethernet cable when practicing on the practice field.

System checks: before and after every match perform a systems check of all robot functions. This can help catch issues before you see them during a match. Sometimes you can address them, other times you don’t but you’ll be able to adjust your match strategy as necessary.

Robot maintaince: perform regular robot maintaince through competitions. Things can and will loosen up over time even with nyclock nuts or loctite. Things like tread wear out over time and gears need to be re-greased occasionally. Check for carpet strands caught in your drivetrain.

Take care of your batteries: Don’t carry them by the wires! Keep them on the charger and always use a battery beak before stuffing a battery into your robot.

Packing list: When packing for a competition, have a plan! Come up with a packing list to help you stay organized. If you forget something, make sure to add it to the packing list for next time.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked:
Charge the driverstation laptop and plug it in when on the Field.

If you have the habit of drilling metal things over electronics make sure they are covered extremely well.

posts.name: Jeffrey Dunn
posts.cooked: We had this happen in testing thankfully but always make sure your swerve drives screws are tightened as it’s no fun when a wheel falls off.

Metal bending. Aluminum (and most materials really) experience extremely high stresses under bending and will fail. Sheet metal should never have significant normal loading, shafts and standoffs should never experience significant bending loads, and boxtube should never be loaded normal to the center of the faces.

Bad loading cases can be avoided by either adding more more material in the correct direction which can withstand the load or adding compliance in the mechanism (polycarb, forcing mechanism to retract, springs…) to reduce the force experienced during impacts.

posts.name: Carter Steggerda
posts.cooked: Zip tie your battery connections!! Also make sure your controllers are chosen correctly on the drivers station (check twice).

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
In addition to this at multiple events we have seen teams have failed optifuse main breakers mostly due to the plastic cracking in various part of the breaker.

We won’t be using the optifuse brand main breakers on any of our competition robots and I suggest other teams use the Bussmann brand that has been reliable for many years before as well.

link_counts.title: One rule change that will improve everyone's season: Ban the Optifuse!

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked: One of the nice ways we do this is that during disabled if you click the A button on our driver controller the LEDs on our robot display white, and the a button on the operator controller lights them yellow. This is a faster check then having to go to the controller menu in the driver station app.

posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked:
I am of the opinion that HQ should outright ban the optifuse main breakers but I’m not going to win any friends for saying this out loud.

These things should not be on robots.  The failure potential is too high.  I don’t think it’s a bad batch either - it’s all of them.

posts.name: Marcus Kauffman
posts.cooked:
image 1920×2560 240 KB Not sure what this is or what problem it was supposed to solve, but it caused multiple electrical issues. Don’t solder 6AWG wire.

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked:
General issues I see as CSA/RI:

Don’t baby your robot at the shop.  You will have time to fix anything you break by doing rough drive practice, you don’t want to be fixing those errors at a comp.

Mount your radio high and away from your other electronics!

Using a network switch on your robot and the barrel connector giving you trouble?  Buy a brainbox or other style industrial switch that designed for shock/vibration and that is either powered with screw terminals or POE.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: I also highly recommend buying a 12V automotive inverter to mount on your cart and hook up to retired robot batteries.  That way you can keep charging your laptop in queue and even power something like a glue gun.  I’m a big fan of this one for $35 that has screw terminals, mounting holes, high output, and a battery gauge

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
As much as I don’t like singling out a company’s product, I’ve seen REV’s orange POE injector cable continue to fail teams. I’ve known them to internally fail causing intermittent data loss (which can manifest as just a little packet loss when physically disturbed, or full comms loss) since 2018, and nothing seems to have changed. The issue seems to be entirely with the data (Ethernet pass-through) portion of the cable; they do a good job of keeping the radio on.

On the flip side, their radio power module is so reliable I failed to diagnose a (brief) full battery short a team was seeing during collisions for most of an event because the only power failure I had evidence of was to the RIO. Probably over a dozen battery shorts, and their radio didn’t drop connection to the FMS once. Rather impressive.

marshall:

Loose main power wires?

Only my second year as a CSA , but I saw this more this year than any other I recall - including on my own team. No idea if there’s any particular reason for this.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
At our Hartsville event we determined the battery holding straps we were using weren’t sufficient. The problem was more that the buckle we had on the crossing strap kept failing repeatedly. We replaced that strap system with long inverted 1/4” bolts and a thick retaining bar with through holes drilled into it. Then we use thumbscrews to tighten it down (similar to our bumper mounting/retaining system.) No more loose batteries. We had one team at the PCH CMP learn the same lesson as us and they implemented a similar solution at the event.

Robots work better with the battery still inside them.

posts.name: chrisrin
posts.cooked:
Adding one I just remembered:

Failure: Autonomous routine did not run after it was selected, because field was subsequently reset & robot powered off/on at field crew request, and we did not (know we needed to) reselect the auto routine. Fix: Just something drive team needs to know I guess… need to reselect auto under those circumstances. I suppose this depends on how your auto routine selection solution is set up. I remember reading years ago about a team having a physical auto multi-selector on the robot, and that approach should not fail.

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked:
Don’t drill into aluminum over gear boxes, electronics, or other important parts of the robot.

Don’t use loctite on a bolt that may touch polycarb. It eats away at the plastic.

Spend the time looking for leaks in pneumatics.
